entry.title: Digital Identity website
entry.content:
{% include project-detail.html %}

An exciting project to be a part of. Building the official public website for the Australian Government's Digital Identity was very rewarding.

Website design and development

The Digital Identity website was developed using Drupal 8. The design and theme was customised using the Australian Government Design System as guidance, ensuring that WCAG 2.1 Guidelines (Level AA) were adhered to. Making sure content is accessibile should always be a top priority for any website project.

The website content, information architecture, and the overall website structure was tested with users to see if users could successfully (and easily) find the information they were seeking. With the user research findings, we were able to make evidence-based content changes. It was extremely valuable to be able to test with users and get insights that we wouldn’t have known had we only tested with internal users.

{% include project-nav-footer.html %}
entry.summary: Previous project Digital Identity website While working at the Digital Transformation Agency, I was the User Experience Design lead, and lead Developer for the Digital Identity website project (putting on my unicorn hat!). Working together with stakeholders, I provided guidance on best-practice, and developed the entire site in Drupal 8. The website was successfully launched in November 2020. Visit digitialidentity.gov.au

entry.title: Engineers Australia
entry.content:
{% include project-detail.html %}

Engineers Australia Online Portal

Engineers Australia had a major redesign to its public website. The website was given a modern look and feel, and the overarching structure of the site was improved.

Engineers Australia's online customer Portal was not included in the redesign. This caused a jarring experience for users when transitioning between the website and Portal.

As the UX designer, I was responsible for improving the user experience of the Portal. We had a lot of feedback from existing users about their experience using the Portal (this was a great starting point!). There were a lot of pain-point areas for users that had to do with poor navigation. This project was not just about redesigning the Portal. There was clear evidence that we needed to fix the information architecture as well.

I arranged workshops with stakeholders to discuss how we might make the experience better for users. The next stage involved design iteration, prototyping, and testing assumptions with users.

Online Chartered application

I was the design lead for EA's online "Chartered" (a status you can achieve as an engineer) application. The application had to cater for non-members, members, and staff (assessors) to manage applications.

There was an existing online application for Chartered, but it was very outdated and clunky (a lot of user dropouts). The application was in need of a redesign and enhancement to the experience. That's where I came in: working with stakeholders, I helped redesign the application. From wireframing, hi-fidelity prototyping right through to front-end development. I was responsible for getting the design created and developed.

There was a lot of work involved in this project, as it wasn't only a redesign of the look and feel. It was an entire redesign of the user journey. This project had a very tight deadline, but the team worked hard and delivered a successful application on time.


Online Chartered application (staff mangement)

Online Chartered application (third party management)

{% include project-nav-footer.html %}
entry.summary: Previous project Next project Engineers Australia While working at Engineers Australia (EA), I was responsible for enhancing the user experience of EA's online offerings. My role also involved designing user interfaces, and the front-end development of these interfaces. I really enjoy hybrid roles where I can use a mixture of my skills to bring a product to life! Visit Engineers Australia website Engineers Australia Online Portal Engineers Australia had a major redesign to its public website. The website was given a modern look and feel, and the overarching structure of the site was improved. Engineers Australia's online customer Portal was not included in the redesign. This caused a jarring experience for users when transitioning between the website and Portal. As the UX designer, I was responsible for improving the user experience of the Portal. We had a lot of feedback from existing users about their experience using the Portal (this was a great starting point!). There were a lot of pain-point areas for users that had to do with poor navigation. This project was not just about redesigning the Portal. There was clear evidence that we needed to fix the information architecture as well. I arranged workshops with stakeholders to discuss how we might make the experience better for users. The next stage involved design iteration, prototyping, and testing assumptions with users.

entry.title: Defence Housing Australia
entry.content:
{% include project-detail.html %}

DHA Online Services

I was responsible for the redesign of DHA's Online Services. This involved modernising the look and feel, making the interface responsive, and improving the user experience for defence members by addressing user pain points. Consistent feedback from members told us the interface was difficult to navigate and users could not find what they needed to access.

The new UI addressed the product's user needs, such as:

  • make it easy for me to know my housing details.
  • make it easy for me to get access to housing services.
  • make it easy for me to find new properties, so I have a place to live when I'm deployed.

Kiosk App UI

Sometimes defence members don't have internet access or reliable internet connection when deployed to regional areas. As DHA's Online Services is primarily online, it became increasingly apparent that users needed access to DHA's online services when visting a regional DHA Member Service branch.

We spoke to users in regional areas, and asked them how we might help make access to online services easier for them. We found that there was a desire for users to be able to do tasks themselves, but still get help if needed. As a potential solution, we trialed using kiosks (locked-down iPad on a stand) in reigonal DHA Member Service branches. This was a relatiely quick fix, and if it worked, would be very cost-effective to roll-out.

The kiosk trial worked very well, with members providing positive feedback. I designed a simple Kiosk user interface to accomodate entry into DHA's Online Services, and informational tutorials related to using DHA Online Services.

Members in regional areas that may not have internet, now have access to DHA's Online Services.

Video text transcript

DHA public website

DHA's Online Services's user interface was updated, so there was a need (from a branding perspective) to align the design of the DHA public website to be consistent with DHA'S Online Services.

I was the project lead and liaised with different areas of DHA to ensure that requirements were being met when redesigning the website. As DHA is a government website, it was important for the website to adhere to WCAG 2.0 Accessibility guidelines. To ensure the DHA website met WCAG 2.0, content changes and semantic code changes were a fundamental part of this project.

{% include project-nav-footer.html %}
entry.summary: Previous project Next project Defence Housing Australia While working at Defence Housing Australia (DHA), I helped redesign and development DHA's public-facing website, deisgn the UI for DHA's online services application, and assist in designing users interfaces for various other applications and systems. Visit DHA website

entry.title: Urban Roasters
entry.content:
{% include project-detail.html %}

Website design and development

I built a highly-customised e-commerce website for Urban Roasters. The website helps people easily purchase once-off coffee and coffee subscription orders online.

I also designed the theme and suite of user interface patterns for Urban Roasters, ensuring a consistent look and feel across their e-commerce platform.

Logo design

I designed a unique logo for Urban Roasters. The "UR" logo mark subtley hints at coffee beans with the applied shape, while also incorporating the initials of the business name (Urban Roasters).

{% include project-nav-footer.html %}
entry.summary: Previous project Next project Urban roasters Urban Roasters is a boutique coffee roastery located in Canberra. This project involved the design and creation of the Urban Roasters logo along with custom graffiti-style artwork. Urban Roasters did not have an existing online presence, and so I was in charge of the full design and development of Urban Roaster's online coffee store. Visit urbanroasters.com.au
